problem: Two blocks of mass m₁ and m₂ respectively are placed on a frictionless surface. The block m₂ is initially at rest, and attached with a spring of spring constant k on its back. The block m₁ is then given an initial speed v₀ and collides head onto the block m₂. (a) What is the maximum compression of the spring throughout the entire collision process? (b) Find the velocities v₁f and v₂f of the two blocks respectively after the collision process. What is the condition on m₁ and m₂ such that the block m₁ will move backwards after the collision?

correctFormulas.name: Energy stored at maximum compression
correctFormulas.formula: ½ m₁ v₀² − ½ (m₁ + m₂) v_c² = ½ k x₍max₎²

correctFormulas.name: Elastic-collision speeds
correctFormulas.formula: v₁f = (m₁ − m₂)/(m₁ + m₂) v₀,  v₂f = 2 m₁ /(m₁ + m₂) v₀

steps.explanation: (a) At maximum compression both blocks share a common speed v_c = m₁ v₀ /(m₁ + m₂). The loss of kinetic energy equals the spring energy.
steps.notations: ½ k x₍max₎² = ½ m₁ v₀² − ½ (m₁ + m₂) v_c² ⇒ x₍max₎ = √[m₁ m₂ v₀² / ((m₁ + m₂) k)]

steps.explanation: (b) Because the interaction is elastic (spring), use 1-D elastic-collision relations.
steps.notations: v₁f = [(m₁ − m₂)/(m₁ + m₂)] v₀,   v₂f = [2 m₁/(m₁ + m₂)] v₀

steps.explanation: Block m₁ moves backward when v₁f < 0, i.e., when m₂ > m₁.
